explanation:
For checking use of compiler/language extensions you must inspect any macros, typedefs and declarations that could hide compiler-specific extensions (attributes, calling conventions, builtin intrinsics, inline asm, anonymous/zero-length arrays, nonstandard keywords, __declspec/__attribute__, etc.). Explanations:

- _MHD_EXTERN: This macro may expand to compiler-specific storage-class or visibility annotations (e.g. __attribute__((visibility)), __declspec(dllexport), other extensions). Its expansion must be checked to detect language extensions.

- MHD_USE_POSIX_THREADS and MHD_USE_W32_THREADS: These configuration macros control whether thread-related code is compiled. Their presence determines whether the mutex helper calls are included; you must know their definitions/values to examine the compiled code path for extensions introduced there.

- MHD_mutex_lock_chk_, MHD_mutex_unlock_chk_, MHD_mutex_destroy_chk_: Inspect their prototypes/definitions because they may be macros or inline functions that use compiler extensions (builtin intrinsics, attributes, calling-convention keywords, inline asm, or platform-specific typedefs). They may also be defined differently per platform (POSIX vs Windows) and introduce extensions.

- struct MHD_Response: The struct definition must be examined to ensure no fields use compiler extensions (e.g. __attribute__, anonymous/unnamed structs/unions if not standard in the targeted language dialect, zero-length arrays as flexible-array extensions, nonstandard bit-field types or attributes, platform-specific calling conventions on function-pointer members).

- struct MHD_HTTP_Res_Header: Its definition is walked in the loop and fields (header, value, next) may use nonstandard declarations (zero-length arrays, attributes). Check for any extension usage in this type.

- response->crfc (the callback type): The callback pointer type stored in the response may carry calling-convention specifiers or attributes (e.g. __stdcall, __attribute__((__cdecl__)), or other extensions). You must inspect its typedef/prototype to determine if a language extension is used.

- response->data_iov (its declared type): The type of data_iov (likely an iovec or custom type) may rely on platform headers that contain extensions (e.g., nonstandard flexible arrays, attributes). Inspect its declaration to ensure no compiler extensions are present.

Note: Standard library identifiers used here (NULL, free) are from the standard C library and generally do not constitute language extensions, so they need not be listed unless their headers/macros have been redefined in this project. The listed symbols are the minimal additional definitions needed to determine whether the target function or the types/macros it uses employ compiler-specific language extensions.
